content: I've edited some formatting and punctuation of the statement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle! Thanks!
However, I cannot pass with Clojure, switch to Python with same idea and passed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle. Multiple solutions need to be properly managed. The optimization is not necessarily obvious for the last tests. Good work !
timeout for the 59O T^T

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Finding a working algorithm isn't complicated, the interesting part comes from the optimizations required to solve the last test cases.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Interesting, I'll try to solve

The requirements are clear.
The solution is not trivial, so this is an interesting and challenging one.
Well done !
Easy to understand, take a time to solve it but still easy to find a solution. Good trainning !

Nice one !
Quite simple to understand and to get a first working version.
Then you go to the optimization part and it gets nicer.
Tried to resolve it in Ruby but still timeouts for the "59 digits" one ;-)

You should change:
"where were the plus signs" => "the positions of the plus signs"
"In some case, there is no solution, then print "No solution", in others just one, print the solution, and others more than one, then print the solutions in lexicographic order ( 1+11 before 11+1 )." => "If there is no solution , then print "No solution", otherwise print the solution(s) in lexicographic order ( 1+11 before 11+1 )."
"string(s) from O and N-1 plus signs = S so as the addition is true" => "formatted as a valid equation I1+I2+..+IN=S "

In constraints:
2 <= N <=10

The difficulty Medium isn't justified. You can pass all the tests & validators without timeout by simply checking every possible combinations. For medium you should add cases where if you don't optimize your solution you're gonna get a timeout.
It's exactly N chunks or up to N chunks

Goal section
* Please fix the typo "dissapeared" to "disappeared".
* Suggest to delete the word "validator" as it seems to imply that the solution is not unique in the non-validator cases?

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Thank you for your remarks (sorry, my english is not fluent)
In the general case, the solution may be 0, 1 or n>1...
for example with n=10 and s=2581 and o=32177654435114223221674933
you have
32+17+765+44+351+142+232+216+749+33=2581
32+177+654+435+11+42+232+216+749+33=2581
that's why I have chosen for validation 1-solution case.
Exactly N chunks. "N is the number of terms in the addition(s) to recover"

Thank you. I have changed terms as you suggest. And I have added a fifth set of validation with more possible combinations, over 250 millions. Hope brute force can not deal with it without timeout. The truth is I have imagined this puzzle, without being able to write the most optimized solution !

I tried the same kind of optimization from your solution.
But still cannot make it, maybe Clojure is too slow.

user=> (time (f 7 588589090 "512233456134547454641212454512145664554121245"))

"Elapsed time: 6666.226521 msecs"
((9 5 8 6 7 6 4))
Yeah brute force will definitely time out on the new test case.
If all the cases you have chosen have a single/unique solution, then it's fine to state so. Otherwise there's an issue as the player won't know which solution to choose.
That's right. So I have precised there may be 0, 1 or n solutions, and add in validator a case with 0 solution and another with more than one (with lexicographic ordering).

OK! But better to group the tests and validators in pairs, e.g. the ones with one solution only should appear in pair, the ones with no solution should appear in pair, etc.

Tests and validators should have similar properties, so you need some adjustments to your cases too.
Ok, done it ! First group with unique solutions, second with no solution, third with more than one. Last group with N=10 and one or more solutions.
